concepts.concept_name: Nervous system and brain as control centre
Circulatory system: heart and blood vessels
Respiratory system: lungs and breathing
Sense organs and their functions
Care and protection of body systems

in_scope: Brain as the control centre of the body
Nerves carry messages to and from the brain
Heart pumps blood through blood vessels
Arteries, veins, and capillaries (basic idea)
Lungs help us breathe in oxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide
Five sense organs: eyes, ears, nose, tongue, skin
Functions of each sense organ
Basic care and hygiene of body systems
out_of_scope: Neuron structure and nerve impulse transmission - Introduced in Class 8
Blood composition and blood groups - Introduced in Class 7-8
Gas exchange at alveolar level - Introduced in Class 7
Reflex arc details - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Cell as the basic unit of life
Parts of a cell: membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus
Differences between plant and animal cells
Unicellular and multicellular organisms
Discovery of the cell and use of microscope

in_scope: Cell as the building block of all living things
Discovery of the cell by Robert Hooke
Cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus
Cell wall present in plant cells only
Chloroplasts in plant cells for making food
Larger vacuole in plant cells
Unicellular organisms: amoeba, bacteria
Multicellular organisms: humans, mango tree
Observing cells under a microscope
out_of_scope: Cell organelles in detail (mitochondria, ER, Golgi) - Introduced in Class 7-8
Cell division (mitosis, meiosis) - Introduced in Class 8-9
DNA and chromosomes - Introduced in Class 9
Tissue types and organisation - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Photosynthesis: how plants make food
Requirements and products of photosynthesis
Respiration in plants
Reproduction in plants: seeds and vegetative
Seed germination and conditions for growth

in_scope: Plants make their own food through photosynthesis
Sunlight, water, carbon dioxide needed for photosynthesis
Chlorophyll gives leaves their green colour
Glucose and oxygen are produced
Stomata allow gas exchange in leaves
Plants also respire like animals
Respiration occurs day and night in plants
Seed dispersal: wind, water, animals, bursting
Parts of a seed: seed coat, cotyledon, embryo
Conditions for germination: water, air, warmth
Vegetative reproduction: stem cutting, layering
out_of_scope: Chemical equations for photosynthesis - Introduced in Class 7-8
Light and dark reactions - Introduced in Class 9
ATP and cellular respiration details - Introduced in Class 9
Pollination and fertilisation details - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Adaptation: how animals survive in their habitats
Types of habitats: desert, forest, aquatic, polar
Food chains and food webs
Endangered species and wildlife conservation
Producers, consumers, and decomposers

in_scope: What is adaptation
Desert animals: camel stores fat, desert fox has large ears
Aquatic animals: fish have gills, streamlined body
Polar animals: polar bear has thick fur, penguin has blubber
Forest animals: monkey, deer, tiger
Indian animals: Bengal tiger, Indian elephant, Asiatic lion
Simple food chains with 3-4 organisms
Producers make food, consumers eat, decomposers break down
Endangered species in India: Bengal tiger, one-horned rhinoceros
National parks and wildlife sanctuaries in India
out_of_scope: Trophic levels and energy pyramid - Introduced in Class 8
Natural selection and evolution - Introduced in Class 10
Biogeochemical cycles - Introduced in Class 9
Classification of animals (taxonomy) - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Nutrients: carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals
Balanced diet and its importance
Deficiency diseases
Food preservation methods
Hygiene and cleanliness for good health

in_scope: Six nutrients: carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, water
Functions of each nutrient in the body
Food sources: rice, dal, ghee, fruits, vegetables, milk
A balanced diet contains all nutrients in right amounts
Deficiency diseases: scurvy (Vitamin C), rickets (Vitamin D), anaemia (iron), goitre (iodine), night blindness (Vitamin A)
Food preservation: refrigeration, drying, pickling, canning
Personal hygiene: washing hands, bathing, clean clothes
Food hygiene: washing fruits, covering food, clean water
out_of_scope: Digestive system details - Introduced in Class 6-7
Enzymes and digestion process - Introduced in Class 7
Immunity and antibodies - Introduced in Class 8
Calorie counting and BMI - Higher classes

concepts.concept_name: Three states of matter: solid, liquid, gas
Properties of solids, liquids, and gases
Changes of state: melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation
Physical and chemical changes
The water cycle

in_scope: Three states of matter: solid, liquid, gas
Properties: definite shape, definite volume, compressibility
Arrangement of particles in each state (basic idea)
Melting: solid to liquid
Freezing: liquid to solid
Evaporation: liquid to gas
Condensation: gas to liquid
Physical change: reversible, no new substance formed
Chemical change: irreversible, new substance formed
Examples of physical changes: ice melting, dissolving sugar
Examples of chemical changes: burning, rusting, cooking
Water cycle: evaporation, condensation, precipitation, collection
out_of_scope: Plasma state - Higher classes
Kinetic theory of matter - Introduced in Class 9
Latent heat and boiling/melting points - Introduced in Class 8
Chemical reactions and equations - Introduced in Class 7-8

concepts.concept_name: Types of forces: push, pull, gravity, friction, magnetic
Friction and its effects
Simple machines: lever, pulley, inclined plane, wheel and axle
Forms of energy: heat, light, sound, electrical, kinetic, potential
Energy conservation and transformation

in_scope: Force is a push or pull
Effects of force: change speed, direction, or shape
Types: muscular, gravitational, frictional, magnetic
Contact and non-contact forces
Friction opposes motion
Friction is useful (walking, brakes) and harmful (wear and tear)
Simple machines make work easier
Examples: scissors (lever), flagpole (pulley), ramp (inclined plane)
Forms of energy: heat, light, sound, electrical, kinetic, potential
Energy can change from one form to another
Energy cannot be created or destroyed
out_of_scope: Newton's laws of motion - Introduced in Class 9
Formulas for work, energy, power - Introduced in Class 8-9
Mechanical advantage calculations - Introduced in Class 8
Types of levers (Class 1, 2, 3) - Introduced in Class 7

concepts.concept_name: Air pollution: causes and effects
Water pollution: causes and effects
Land pollution and waste management
Conservation and the 3Rs: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle
Climate change basics and global warming

in_scope: Air pollution: vehicle smoke, factory fumes, burning waste
Effects of air pollution: breathing problems, smog
Water pollution: factory waste, sewage, pesticides in rivers
Effects of water pollution: diseases, harm to aquatic life
Land pollution: plastic waste, garbage, chemical dumping
Reduce, Reuse, Recycle (3Rs)
Biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste
Planting trees and afforestation
Basic idea of global warming: Earth getting warmer
Simple actions to protect the environment
out_of_scope: Greenhouse effect in detail - Introduced in Class 8
Ozone layer depletion - Introduced in Class 8
Sustainable development - Introduced in Class 9
Environmental laws and policies - Higher classes

concepts.concept_name: Cultural diversity of India: languages, religions, and traditions
Festivals of India: religious and national celebrations
National symbols and national integration
Traditional clothing, food, and art forms across states
Living together in harmony: respect for all cultures

in_scope: India is a land of many languages, religions, and cultures
22 official languages in the Eighth Schedule of the Constitution
Hindi and English as link languages
Major religions: Hinduism, Islam, Christianity, Sikhism, Buddhism, Jainism
Major festivals: Diwali, Eid, Christmas, Baisakhi, Pongal, Onam, Bihu, Holi
National symbols: flag, emblem, anthem, animal (tiger), bird (peacock), flower (lotus)
Traditional clothing: saree, dhoti, salwar kameez, lungi, mekhela chador
Traditional food and dance forms from different states
Unity in Diversity as India's strength
Respecting all religions and cultures equally
out_of_scope: Detailed history of religions - Higher classes
Linguistic reorganisation of states - Class 7-8
Detailed study of tribal cultures - Higher classes
Comparative religion studies - Higher classes

concepts.concept_name: British rule in India and its impact
Key freedom fighters: Gandhi, Nehru, Bose, Bhagat Singh, Rani Laxmi Bai
Important events: Salt March, Quit India Movement, Non-Cooperation
Independence Day and Republic Day significance
Values of the freedom movement: non-violence, courage, sacrifice

in_scope: British East India Company came for trade and gradually took over India
Revolt of 1857: first war of Indian independence, Rani Laxmi Bai, Mangal Pandey
Mahatma Gandhi: Father of the Nation, non-violence (ahimsa), Dandi March (1930)
Jawaharlal Nehru: first Prime Minister, Chacha Nehru, Children's Day (14 November)
Subhash Chandra Bose: Netaji, Indian National Army (INA), 'Give me blood, I will give you freedom'
Bhagat Singh: young revolutionary, sacrifice for freedom at age 23
Quit India Movement (1942): 'Do or Die'
Independence Day: 15 August 1947, first tricolour at Red Fort
Republic Day: 26 January 1950, Constitution came into effect
Non-violence, satyagraha, swadeshi as methods of protest
out_of_scope: Detailed timeline of British rule - Class 7-8
Partition details and communal issues - Class 8
Economic exploitation in detail - Class 8-9
Detailed study of all movements - Class 7-8

concepts.concept_name: The Indian Constitution: what it is and why it matters
Fundamental rights and duties of citizens
Parliament, President, and Prime Minister
Elections and voting in a democracy
Panchayati Raj and local self-government

in_scope: Constitution is the supreme law of India, adopted on 26 January 1950
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar: Father of the Indian Constitution, chairman of the Drafting Committee
Fundamental Rights: Right to Equality, Right to Freedom, Right against Exploitation, Right to Education
Fundamental Duties: respect national symbols, protect environment, develop scientific temper
India is a democratic republic: people elect their leaders
Parliament: Lok Sabha (House of the People) and Rajya Sabha (Council of States)
President is the head of state; Prime Minister is the head of government
Elections: every adult (18+) has the right to vote
Panchayati Raj: Gram Panchayat, Panchayat Samiti, Zilla Parishad
Local self-government helps people solve problems at village and town level
out_of_scope: Detailed constitutional articles - Class 8-9
Separation of powers in detail - Class 7-8
Judicial system and courts - Class 7-8
Political parties and coalition governments - Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Physical features: Himalayas, plains, plateaus, deserts, coasts
Major rivers of India and their importance
Climate and seasons of India
States, Union Territories, and their capitals
Neighbouring countries and India's location

in_scope: India has 28 states and 8 Union Territories
Himalayas: young fold mountains in the north, Mount Everest is the highest peak
Indo-Gangetic Plain: fertile plain formed by rivers Ganga, Yamuna, Brahmaputra
Deccan Plateau: large triangular plateau in southern India
Thar Desert: in western Rajasthan, hot and sandy
Coastal plains along the Arabian Sea and Bay of Bengal
Major rivers: Ganga, Yamuna, Brahmaputra, Godavari, Krishna, Narmada, Kaveri
Three main seasons: summer, monsoon (rainy), winter
India is in South Asia, bordered by Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Sri Lanka
Important states and their capitals
out_of_scope: Detailed geological formation of landforms - Class 8-9
Detailed climate classification - Class 7-8
Agriculture and crop patterns - Class 7
Population distribution and density - Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Globe as a model of the Earth
Continents and oceans of the world
Latitude and longitude: basic introduction
Map symbols, scale, and directions
Reading and understanding simple maps

in_scope: A globe is a small model of the Earth showing its round shape
A map is a flat drawing of the Earth's surface or a part of it
Seven continents: Asia, Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica, Europe, Australia
Five oceans: Pacific, Atlantic, Indian, Southern (Antarctic), Arctic
India is in Asia, surrounded by the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, and Bay of Bengal
Latitude: horizontal lines, Equator is 0 degrees latitude
Longitude: vertical lines, Prime Meridian is 0 degrees longitude
Four main directions: North, South, East, West
Map symbols: blue for water, green for forests, brown for mountains
Map scale: helps measure real distances on a map
out_of_scope: Projection types and map distortion - Class 8-9
Detailed coordinate system calculations - Class 7-8
Time zones and International Date Line - Class 7
Topographic maps and contour lines - Class 8-9

concepts.concept_name: Right to Education and child labour awareness
Gender equality and respect for all
Environmental responsibility and sustainable habits
Disability awareness and inclusion
Responsible citizenship: duties and good behaviour

in_scope: Every child has the right to free and compulsory education (ages 6-14)
Right to Education Act (RTE) 2009
Child labour is wrong and illegal: children should study and play, not work
Boys and girls are equal and deserve the same opportunities
Girls should have equal access to education, sports, and career choices
Protecting the environment: saving water, electricity, planting trees
People with disabilities deserve respect, support, and equal opportunities
Ramps, Braille, sign language help people with different abilities
Being a responsible citizen: following rules, helping others, respecting elders
Community service and caring for public property
out_of_scope: Detailed labour laws and policies - Higher classes
Gender studies and feminism in depth - Higher classes
Detailed disability legislation - Higher classes
Social reform movements in history - Class 7-8
